text.text: Welcome to the Graphics & Games Digital Lounge!

blocks.alt_text: A multi-colored outline of a game controller on a black background

text.text: Welcome to the WWDC22 Graphics & Games Digital Lounge! We‚Äôve got an exciting week planned for you. You can find the full schedule of events in the <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=nihd4qal| Apple Developer app and on developer.apple.com>, and activities for all lounges kick off on June 7.
If you haven't already, please take a moment to familiarize yourself with <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=735utu4s|how the Digital Lounges will work>.

We want to make sure these spaces are helpful and welcoming for everyone ‚Äî developers and Apple employees alike. Please review and follow the <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/policies/interactive-events/1/Apple-Developer-WWDC22-Interactive-Events-Attendance-Policy.pdf| WWDC22 Interactive Events Policy>.

messages.text:
:relaxed: Welcome to Meet the Presenter: Discover Metal 3. We‚Äôre incredibly excited to have you with us today. I‚Äôm Preston, a Metal engineer in GPU Software. Digital lounge activities are meant to bring developers and Apple employees together virtually. And this is our very first lounge for Metal, which makes it all the more exciting. This lounge is a watch party followed by Q & A after the video completes. In this hour, for a great experience, we would like to ask you to start watching <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10066/|the video> (<https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10066/|Discover Metal 3>: <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10066/>) at 9:05am.

In the meantime, we‚Äôre excited to introduce you to the speaker, Tarun, Program Manager in GPU Software :clap:. In addition, we‚Äôre joined here by many folks from the Metal team, ready to answer your questions! There‚Äôs a lot of us here, so we‚Äôre going to do our best to keep things organized.

As the video progresses, I‚Äôll be creating threads :thread: associated with each section of the talk, where everyone can chat and react. After the video has finished playing, please stick around! We will open a slack workflow so that you can submit your questions to the Metal team. The team and I will be hanging around after the video has finished to begin answering as many questions as we can.

In this talk, we‚Äôll introduce you to the latest features, improvements, and tooling that are coming to Metal :exploding_head:. So, make sure you have your popcorn :popcorn: ready and feel free to drop a reaction or join in on the conversation when you see something that interests :raised_hands: you!

Feel free to ask us anything! The team won‚Äôt bite and are ready for your questions :relieved:. We are busy compiling some responses now :gear:
If you just want to hang out, that's fine too - we would love to know a little bit more about how you use Metal, so maybe you would like to take a short quiz and see what others are up to as well :face_with_monocle:? Post your answers on this thread :nerd_face:!

:one:. What was your first ray tracing experience? Sphere? Cornell Box? Bunny? Moana?
:two:. What devices and what resolutions do you typically target for your games?
:three:. Do you compress your assets and textures? Block compression (ASTC/BC)? Lossless compression?
:four:. How do you determine the default resolution and graphics settings for a given device at first launch?
:five:. How have you been training your networks until now :muscle:?
:six:. Did you ever wish to add your own operation to ML pipeline?
:seven:. What custom operations do you need in your network?

1. SceneKit shadermodifier-based raytracing with caustics
2. 1080p with uikit-based upscaling, so I'm thinking about MetalFX:)
3. No compression. I haven't seen great posts/examples with explanation about compression options and differences.
4. From UIDevice, but will have to switch to a family-based approach, I think.
5. PyTorch
6. Yes, yes, I did. But we work with ANE acceleration, and it's not programmable, sadly, and we are loading our GPU with rendering to the point of overheating in 5 minutes on older devices:(
7. A lot of small ones, usually. ATM we are fallbacking to CPU/GPU due to floordiv and sqrt

messages.text:
<@U03HZ4PT2ER> asked
> There any main tradeoffs between tessellation and mesh shading for vertex creation?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"There any main tradeoffs between tessellation and mesh shading for vertex creation?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Mesh Shading has a more flexible workflow and allows for dynamic scaling of your workload through the object shader stage. In terms of performance, Mesh Shading allows a more pipelined flow directly from the Mesh Shader stage to the rasterizer, so you have full mesh visibility during vertex creation. On the other hand - I would suggest using tessellation if you are doing actual tessellation of an existing geometry pipeline.

elements.text: Mesh Shading has a more flexible workflow and allows for dynamic scaling of your workload through the object shader stage. In terms of performance, Mesh Shading allows a more pipelined flow directly from the Mesh Shader stage to the rasterizer, so you have full mesh visibility during vertex creation. On the other hand - I would suggest using tessellation if you are doing actual tessellation of an existing geometry pipeline.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: For users who are doing procedural work that doesn't directly map to tessellation per-se, I would definitely suggest Mesh Shaders.

elements.text: For users who are doing procedural work that doesn't directly map to tessellation per-se, I would definitely suggest Mesh Shaders.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The new <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/metal_sample_code_library/adjusting_the_level_of_detail_using_metal_mesh_shaders?language=objc|sample code> we published shows how mesh shaders work and you can get an idea of the difference.

elements.text: we published shows how mesh shaders work and you can get an idea of the difference.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The sample code generates Bezier patches and uses mesh shaders to control the level of detail. While the patches are generated on the CPU, you will see that it would not be a huge leap to do that in the object stage or mesh stage.

elements.text: The sample code generates Bezier patches and uses mesh shaders to control the level of detail. While the patches are generated on the CPU, you will see that it would not be a huge leap to do that in the object stage or mesh stage.

The documentation, tooling and APIs seems better than ever and the MetalFX Upscaling seems a game changer. I can see some foveated rendering hacks being used with this API and using different LOD with the fast resource. Cheers lads, awesome work.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks for the feedback. We are curious about your idea "I can see some foveated rendering hacks being used with this API". Can you elaborate more on it?

elements.text: Thanks for the feedback. We are curious about your idea "I can see some foveated rendering hacks being used with this API". Can you elaborate more on it?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Using the same concept that VR googles are starting now but on a flat screen. Render the main point of interest in 4k and moving away from it, create lower zones (almost like a gradient) where the borders can be rendered at like 1080p with high anti alias combining with lower LOD. Again, starting so not even sure if it‚Äôs possible.

elements.text: Using the same concept that VR googles are starting now but on a flat screen. Render the main point of interest in 4k and moving away from it, create lower zones (almost like a gradient) where the borders can be rendered at like 1080p with high anti alias combining with lower LOD. Again, starting so not even sure if it‚Äôs possible.

For foveated rendering there‚Äôs also a variable rasterization rate API in Metal to help with that

elements.text: For foveated rendering there‚Äôs also a variable rasterization rate API in Metal to help with that

messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I\u2019m learning graphics (coming from Swift) and am really interested in Ray tracing. What should I learn first to learn how to make a hybrid renderer in Metal?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi Ethan! In addition to this year's Raytracing content, we also had a session fully dedicated to the topic of Hybrid Rendering in last year's WWDC. Hopefully you find it a good introduction to the topic - <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10150/>. In particular, the session shows how to do your "primaries" using rasterization, and then how to use that as the basis for RT Shadows, Ambient Occlusion, and Mirror-like Reflections.

messages.text: Today we explored some of the advanced features and tools coming in Metal 3 :exploding_head:. These features and tools will enable your application or game to load resources faster, compile shader binaries at build time, process complex geometry with mesh shaders, render high-resolution graphics in less time, train machine learning networks faster, and much more. On behalf of the Metal team, thank you for joining this watch party and celebrating WWDC with us :relaxed:! We enjoyed the questions you asked and look forward to seeing what amazing apps and games you all will make with Metal 3 :partying_face:.

<@U03HMC1PAG7> asked
> Since the shaders are compiled at project build time and compilation speed is no longer as critical, is that extra headroom used to allow the compiler to try to optimize the shaders further? Or is does it produce identical machine code as when building it at runtime?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Since the shaders are compiled at project build time and compilation speed is no longer as critical, is that extra headroom used to allow the compiler to try to optimize the shaders further? Or is does it produce identical machine code as when building it at runtime?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Independent from offline compilation, we did introduce a new optimization level -Os (size) as an option, but there is not additional optimization that occurs during runtime. The produced code will be identical.

elements.text: Independent from offline compilation, we did introduce a new optimization level -Os (size) as an option, but there is not additional optimization that occurs during runtime. The produced code will be identical.

messages.text:
<@U03JSFUKL2U> asked
> Can you explain how to use triple buffering for complicated scene with 2d (overlay/ui) and 3d? What kind of data I should store in buffers? In Vulkan examples they use framebuffer, but metal dont have any similar entity.
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Can you explain how to use triple buffering for complicated scene with 2d (overlay\/ui) and 3d? What kind of data I should store in buffers? In Vulkan examples they use framebuffer, but metal dont have any similar entity."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Could you give a bit more context? In general all interfacing with the compositing is done through the Drawable. (usually through a MTKView in an app). Are you referring to manually triple-buffering GPU resources for CPU synchronization?

elements.text: Could you give a bit more context? In general all interfacing with the compositing is done through the Drawable. (usually through a MTKView in an app). Are you referring to manually triple-buffering GPU resources for CPU synchronization?

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Yeah, indeed. I wanna fill some data on CPU side while frame rendering (inflight frames) and pass filled buffer to command queue. In apple examples I see how to use inflight frames to fill camera data to buffers, but camera data isn't complicated.

Im newbie in Metal and trying to create my own render engine.

One way to do this is to have a set of data for each frame in flight. You can then use a mutex (or other thread-safe structure) to keep track of what sets are in flight by:
‚Ä¢ marking them when you use them in a command bufferand 
‚Ä¢ unmarking them in the completion handler of the command buffer. 
If you run out of free sets, you can simply wait on the mutex and halt rendering on CPU until GPU has caught up.

"}]}],"style":"bullet","indent":0,"border":0}

elements.text: If you run out of free sets, you can simply wait on the mutex and halt rendering on CPU until GPU has caught up.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Ok, I will try it! Thanks a lot.

check `synchronize` <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/mtlblitcommandencoder/1400775-synchronize|link> and the various ways of signalling and reading data between buffers on GPU and CPU <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/mtlbuffer|link>

elements.text: and the various ways of signalling and reading data between buffers on GPU and CPU

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Also, if you wanted a example of this pattern check out the game template in XCode by creating a new project in Xcode, selecting the `Game` template and picking `Game Technology: Metal` . In that template check how `_inFlightSemaphore` is used to multi buffer the uniforms buffer.

is used to multi buffer the uniforms buffer.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
The main idea is that you shouldn‚Äôt modify data with the CPU if the GPU might be reading it, so using that semaphore with a completion handler (per the examples above) allows you to know when at least one of your 3 copies of any data are able to be modified.

If you are not using the CPU to modify textures/buffers on the fly then there isn‚Äôt a need for this semaphore. -[CAMetalLayer nextDrawable] will automatically provide up to 3 drawables and will limit an app from getting too far ahead (if you render faster than the screen refresh).

Hello everyone and welcome to Meet the Presenter for the session *Plug-in and Play: Add Apple Frameworks to your Unity Projects*

We‚Äôre incredibly excited to have you with us today to watch the session and chat with us about the new Apple Unity plug-ins.

I‚Äôm Jared, an engineer working on Game Technologies and the speaker from today's session. I'm also joined by a number of Apple engineers who have contributed to the plug-ins.

This activity is a watch party followed by a Q&A after the video completes. As the video progresses I‚Äôll be creating threads for each section of the talk where everyone in the channel can chat and react.

After the video has finished playing please stick around for the Q&A! We will enable a slack workflow that allows you to submit any questions that you might have and we'll do our best to answer. (To ask a question, click the plus button (:heavy_plus_sign: ) in the lower left of the chat, then find the "Ask a Question" lightning bolt.)

In order to sync up with everyone and watch together, we'll synchronize our video start time to *11:05 AM PT*. I'll give a message to let you know when I'm kicking off the video on my end.

Thanks for joining!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Unfortunately we don't currently offer a plug-in that exposes this functionality, but this is certainly an interesting idea.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Can you tell me more about what you're trying to do. Are you looking for something that behaves like the share sheet?

elements.text: Can you tell me more about what you're trying to do. Are you looking for something that behaves like the share sheet?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It's more of a thought experiment at this point, but I kind of want to create a fantasy/rpg game and want to incentivize working together in real life to defeat certain bosses or challenges. My goal is to not rely on having any servers if possible. I think having bluetooth access might be a way for people to create a party, like in a typical 4 player rpg game like final fantasy. For example, if you are a healer. You can only heal or buff other people most of the time. In this case to beat certain challenges you would need to meet up with other people to be able to progress.

> What is the recommended framework for connecting to another player stably for a multiplayer match? Not the old turn-based games, but a modern approach to having a 5-10 minute connection for PvP. (Would ARKit, RealityKit be better today than multipeer connectivity, which can be flaky with frequent disconnects?)
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

(Would ARKit, RealityKit be better today than multipeer connectivity, which can be flaky with frequent disconnects?)"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi - GameKit currently provides real time multiplayer support and is currently used in a number of games. Coincidentally, we've just shared this functionality as part of the Unity plug-ins made available today.

elements.text: Hi - GameKit currently provides real time multiplayer support and is currently used in a number of games. Coincidentally, we've just shared this functionality as part of the Unity plug-ins made available today.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Besides that, GameKit provides a few way for our users to play with each other:
‚Ä¢ Auto matching.
‚Ä¢ Inviting Game Center friends via <http://Messages.app|Messages.app> or push notifications.
‚Ä¢ Or play with nearby friends.
You will be able to see some games in Apple Arcade utilizing the multiplayer functionality provided by gamekit.

elements.text: Besides that, GameKit provides a few way for our users to play with each other:

messages.text: We‚Äôre getting some questions about adopting the new game controllers supported by the Game Controller framework this year! Do developers have to make any code changes to take advantage of the newly supported game controllers?

elements.text: We‚Äôre getting some questions about adopting the new game controllers supported by the Game Controller framework this year! Do developers have to make any code changes to take advantage of the newly supported game controllers?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Nope! The newly supported game controllers will be reported to your app as `GCController`objects, just like MFi, Xbox, and PlayStation controllers.  Some new game controllers may not have all of the buttons, thumbsticks, and dpads that are available on MFi, Xbox, and PlayStation controllers. Make sure you are following the best practices outlined in the <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2020/10614/|Advancements in Game Controllers> talk from WWDC20 to make your game compatible with the greatest number of game controllers.

messages.text: Another popular question! You might be wondering, How can I make sure my game is recognized by the App Store as supporting Game Controllers?

elements.text: Another popular question! You might be wondering, How can I make sure my game is recognized by the App Store as supporting Game Controllers?

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Just add the ‚ÄúGame Controllers‚Äù capability to your project in Xcode, and be sure to check ‚ÄúExtended Gamepad‚Äù support.

If you wish to manually set these keys in your Info.plist, set the `GCSupportsControllerUserInteraction` key to YES and add a dictionary entry to your `GCSupportedGameControllers` array with `{"ProfileName" : "ExtendedGamepad"}`. See <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/bundleresources/information_property_list/gcsupportscontrolleruserinteraction|GCSupportrsControllerUserInteraction> and <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/bundleresources/information_property_list/gcsupportedgamecontrollers|GCSupportedGameControllers>.

messages.text: That‚Äôs a wrap! Thank you all for joining us with such great questions. We hope to see you back tomorrow for the Metal 3 Q&A! :the_horns: We‚Äôll also be back here for another Games Q&A on Friday. :joystick:

messages.text:
Hi everybody! Welcome to the Metal Q&A session :relaxed:. We are very excited to have you all with us today. I‚Äôm Jaap, a Metal engineer at Apple. Digital lounge activities are meant to bring developers and Apple employees together virtually, and this is the go-to place to connect with our engineers and ask any questions about rendering on Apple devices using Metal 3 :partying_face:!

One of the big announcements this year was Metal 3, with a set of great new features and enhancements such as Fast Resource Loading, MetalFX, Ray Tracing and Mesh Shaders :exploding_head:. We have already shown off a bit of these new features in our <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10066/|Metal session>! Feel free to ask about new features, rendering, ray tracing, performance tips or maybe how to get started in this crazy world of GPU programming :nerd_face:.

We have a great group of people here today! To keep the chat tidy, we will be using the ask-a-question workflow. Select the :heavy_plus_sign: icon from the lower left, and find the ‚ÄúAsk A Question‚Äù workflow :zap:Ô∏è. Type in your question and it will be delivered directly to the Metal team. Answers will be posted in threads :thread:. Everybody is free to see and contribute to threads, so be sure to keep an eye out for interesting questions from your fellow developers!

More in-depth sessions are becoming available throughout the week :calendar:.

If you think of a question :woman-raising-hand: after the Q+A today don‚Äôt worry! We have another Metal Q&A session planned for Friday so you will have another chance to ask.

messages.text:
<@U03HVCCH5KQ> asked
> Could mesh shaders be used for procedural terrain generation with continuous LOD? Currently I use a tessellation compute shader (which also does some basic culling) followed by a vertex/fragment shader.
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Could mesh shaders be used for procedural terrain generation with continuous LOD? Currently I use a tessellation compute shader (which also does some basic culling) followed by a vertex\/fragment shader."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can definitely use Mesh Shaders to do this! - The great thing about Mesh Shaders is that you are not limited to the fixed tessellation layout; you can kick off an Object Shader to calculate what tiles to populate (and which ones to leave out for custom tiles), and then dynamically schedule Mesh Shader grids to create the individual tile geometry. :)

elements.text: You can definitely use Mesh Shaders to do this! - The great thing about Mesh Shaders is that you are not limited to the fixed tessellation layout; you can kick off an Object Shader to calculate what tiles to populate (and which ones to leave out for custom tiles), and then dynamically schedule Mesh Shader grids to create the individual tile geometry. :)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This way, you could effectively generate and cull your entire terrain on the GPU

elements.text: This way, you could effectively generate and cull your entire terrain on the GPU

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Is there any specific issues you are worried/thinking about?

elements.text: Is there any specific issues you are worried/thinking about?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Fantastic! Are there any more details/docs on mesh shaders? I‚Äôm having trouble finding much about it.

elements.text: Fantastic! Are there any more details/docs on mesh shaders? I‚Äôm having trouble finding much about it.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: One of the problems I have at the moment is culling. I pass in some quads to the tessellator, then do frustum transforms to try to figure out whether the quad would be onscreen or not (using -1 for the tessellation factor if I want to cull it). Then my vertex shader displaces vertices with the procedural function and does the transforms again, and it all feels a bit clunky.

elements.text: One of the problems I have at the moment is culling. I pass in some quads to the tessellator, then do frustum transforms to try to figure out whether the quad would be onscreen or not (using -1 for the tessellation factor if I want to cull it). Then my vertex shader displaces vertices with the procedural function and does the transforms again, and it all feels a bit clunky.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I know there‚Äôs a session tomorrow on mesh shaders, but I‚Äôm having trouble understanding the basic behavior of them atm.

elements.text: I know there‚Äôs a session tomorrow on mesh shaders, but I‚Äôm having trouble understanding the basic behavior of them atm.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
There will be a full session on Mesh Shaders tomorrow! And you can always drop back into the next Q&A on friday if you have any follow-up.

My suggestion for doing these kinds of things, is to assume each "tile" has a AABB of the min/max displacement within the segment (pre-calc if needed), then use the Object Shader (which is a full featured compute shader) to generate work items for tiles of various sizes etc. Then run a Mesh Shader Grid with a TG per tile to generate. You can simply cull your AABB in the OS and you should never have any overhead aside from the AABB check :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:

You can simply cull your AABB in the OS and you should never have any overhead aside from the AABB check

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can effectively have the OS TG fill the payload buffer with an array of TileDesc structs (or something like that), then have each MS TG pick up a TileDesc to expand into a mesh and send it straight to the rasterizer

elements.text: You can effectively have the OS TG fill the payload buffer with an array of TileDesc structs (or something like that), then have each MS TG pick up a TileDesc to expand into a mesh and send it straight to the rasterizer

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Tomorrow's Mesh Shader session will be here: <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10162/>
Documentation will be updated in the near future, and I believe a sample project will be available along with the session.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: OK, this sounds good! Is there any integration with the existing tessellation pipeline, or would I need to somehow implement something like it in the OS or MS?

elements.text: OK, this sounds good! Is there any integration with the existing tessellation pipeline, or would I need to somehow implement something like it in the OS or MS?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I believe you have to do a manual tessellation in your MS. If I can make a suggestion, a doubling straight forward quad tessellation scheme while you fade in height dat through manual mip levels might be a very good and quick way of getting a simple-but-smooth solution. The nice thing about OS/MS is that you can nicely debug both the tile scheduling and the mesh generation separately, as they are both basically compute kernels you can run individually.

elements.text: I believe you have to do a manual tessellation in your MS. If I can make a suggestion, a doubling straight forward quad tessellation scheme while you fade in height dat through manual mip levels might be a very good and quick way of getting a simple-but-smooth solution. The nice thing about OS/MS is that you can nicely debug both the tile scheduling and the mesh generation separately, as they are both basically compute kernels you can run individually.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hmm I see. It definitely sounds like something to try out. I love the built-in tessellator because it distinguishes between internal and edge tessellation which lets me avoid cracks in the terrain. I guess I would just need to do a bit more work in my MS to make that work.

elements.text: Hmm I see. It definitely sounds like something to try out. I love the built-in tessellator because it distinguishes between internal and edge tessellation which lets me avoid cracks in the terrain. I guess I would just need to do a bit more work in my MS to make that work.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I wonder if the current fixed tessellator could be exposed as a function we could call from our MS‚Ä¶

elements.text: I wonder if the current fixed tessellator could be exposed as a function we could call from our MS‚Ä¶

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
I think the main issue with the classic tessellation scheme is that it tends to generate noisy silhouettes when tessellation smoothly increases. (you get this wave-effect as the vertices move across the displacement samples).
There should be a way to integrate an external "classic tessellation function" into the MS kernel to generate a list of 2D triples for a given tessellation. I wouldn't be surprised if there are examples of this online.

elements.text:

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes the swimming vertices are an issue. Although it‚Äôs an issue in my case anyway as I‚Äôm using a single square mesh to render an entire spherical terrain from ground to space by ‚Äúwrapping‚Äù it over the sphere depending on distance and what is potentially visible. My solution is to buy better GPUs and increase the vertex count to minimise the sample aliasing.. :smile:

messages.text:
<@U03HZ4PT2ER> asked
> How should we approach issues like Shader Debugger crashes and GPU faults? We don't know where to look for hints
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"How should we approach issues like Shader Debugger crashes and GPU faults? We don't know where to look for hints"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
The best thing to do for debugger crashes is to create a feedback assistant with steps to reproduce.

As for GPU faults, I would encourage you to try enabling shader validation for your application.

elements.text:
The best thing to do for debugger crashes is to create a feedback assistant with steps to reproduce.

<@U03HZ3REZEH> asked
> Can we somehow cancel work committed to GPU? For example we commit–µed some neural net processing (example of huge work) and we received memory warning from the system, can we somehow stop execution?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Can we somehow cancel work committed to GPU? For example we commit\u0435ed some neural net processing (example of huge work) and we received memory warning from the system, can we somehow stop execution?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi Pavel, unfortunately no facility exists to cancel committed GPU work. You can use Indirect Command Buffers and NOP out the commands before execution though, could that be a work around?

(Also we'd appreciate it if you can file a feedback request with this scenario for us to evaluate.)

elements.text:

messages.text:
<@U03JM1PJE9G> asked
> What is the best way to denoise the Ray traced frame in metal? Is MPSSVGFDenoiser recommended for this purpose?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the best way to denoise the Ray traced frame in metal? Is MPSSVGFDenoiser recommended for this purpose?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: MPSSVGFDenoiser will work for denoising the full application frame. Typically you want a denoiser targeted at each ray traced effect, focusing on the visibility signal for shadows and ambient occlusion, and a separate denoiser for reflections aware of how to reproject reflected content.

elements.text: MPSSVGFDenoiser will work for denoising the full application frame. Typically you want a denoiser targeted at each ray traced effect, focusing on the visibility signal for shadows and ambient occlusion, and a separate denoiser for reflections aware of how to reproject reflected content.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: thanks for the response
:thumbsup:  Denoising is a rapidly moving field and there's several open source options that you could look at adding to your application!

elements.text: Denoising is a rapidly moving field and there's several open source options that you could look at adding to your application!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Those are new topics for me, so sorry if it is a silly question, but what is the latest best way to organize global illumination passes with metal ray tracing then? In my inexperienced understanding it was like: accumulate the light from ~3 bounces and apply denoising to the whole result

elements.text: Those are new topics for me, so sorry if it is a silly question, but what is the latest best way to organize global illumination passes with metal ray tracing then? In my inexperienced understanding it was like: accumulate the light from ~3 bounces and apply denoising to the whole result

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Not a silly question at all! Accumulating light from multiple bounces will result in an approximation to global illumination and will likely be noisy depending on how you define the rays for each bounce.  Typically for later bounces you could accept something more diffuse for your global illumination representation - there's more diffuse representations such as <https://jcgt.org/published/0008/02/01/|Dynamic Diffuse Global Illumination>

messages.text:
<@U03HVCCH5KQ> asked
> What's the most performant way to copy a CALayer into a MTLTexture on iOS?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What's the most performant way to copy a CALayer into a MTLTexture on iOS?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Can you elaborate on your use case? What kind of layer are you trying to copy, and does your app provide the original content of this layer?

elements.text: Can you elaborate on your use case? What kind of layer are you trying to copy, and does your app provide the original content of this layer?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We‚Äôre trying to render Lottie animations into a Metal texture interactively in real-time.

elements.text: We‚Äôre trying to render Lottie animations into a Metal texture interactively in real-time.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Our goal is for a user to be able to drag a Lottie animation around a canvas as it plays and have it composited with other Metal content.

elements.text: Our goal is for a user to be able to drag a Lottie animation around a canvas as it plays and have it composited with other Metal content.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The Lottie library we‚Äôre using renders to a CALayer and we need to copy it into a MTLTexture.

elements.text: The Lottie library we‚Äôre using renders to a CALayer and we need to copy it into a MTLTexture.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Do you know what kind of layer they‚Äôre rendering into? It matters significantly whether the library is also using a CAMetalLayer or if it is using the traditional CALayer drawing APIs.

elements.text: Do you know what kind of layer they‚Äôre rendering into? It matters significantly whether the library is also using a CAMetalLayer or if it is using the traditional CALayer drawing APIs.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I think it‚Äôs not a CAMetalLayer, which is the problem. I think it‚Äôs using CAShapeLayer, CATextLayer, etc. (which are much simpler than implementing text rendering for instance). But it seems to be tricky to then get the result from the CALayer into Metal. On macOS CARenderer seems to permit this but not in iOS
Most generally, the only way to capture the composited appearance of a layer is via CARenderer. You will have difficulty syncing the framerate of this renderer with the display.

elements.text: Most generally, the only way to capture the composited appearance of a layer is via CARenderer. You will have difficulty syncing the framerate of this renderer with the display.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: CARenderer is available on iOS, can you elaborate on your difficulty with it?

elements.text: CARenderer is available on iOS, can you elaborate on your difficulty with it?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hmm.. I could have sworn that CARenderer::rendererWithMTLTexture was not available on iOS.. but the docs says it has been there since iOS 11.
Well, I think that‚Äôs the way to do it, right?

One difference I can think of between macOS and iOS is that iOS makes much heavier use of implicit CATransactions. If you try to render the layer tree while the main queue‚Äôs implicit transaction is still open, you might not capture the latest drawing.

On iOS, to guarantee correct drawing, use UIGraphicsImageRenderer in conjunction with `-[UIView drawViewHierarchyInRect:afterScreenUpdates:YES]`. You can then use the resulting UIImage to populate an MTLTexture. This will not be as fast as using CARenderer directly but it is more likely to be resilient to the complexities of how iOS apps use Core Animation.

elements.text:
One difference I can think of between macOS and iOS is that iOS makes much heavier use of implicit CATransactions. If you try to render the layer tree while the main queue‚Äôs implicit transaction is still open, you might not capture the latest drawing.

On iOS, to guarantee correct drawing, use UIGraphicsImageRenderer in conjunction with

. You can then use the resulting UIImage to populate an MTLTexture. This will not be as fast as using CARenderer directly but it is more likely to be resilient to the complexities of how iOS apps use Core Animation.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: But do try CARenderer first. :slightly_smiling_face:
Thanks, I‚Äôll take another look!
Good luck! If neither approach works for you, please file Feedback so the teams involved can understand more about your use case.

elements.text: Good luck! If neither approach works for you, please file Feedback so the teams involved can understand more about your use case.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Devices with an XDR display currently support EDR as long as the device brightness isn't set too high (among other factors) which would clamp those EDR values. Please see <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/hdr_content/determining_support_for_edr_values?language=objc> for more details. On macOS, you can read the `maximumPotentialExtendedDynamicRangeColorComponentValue` property on an `NSScreen` object for that display. And on iOS, you can use `UIScreen.potentialEDRHeadroom`.

messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"More out of curiosity, what are the potential use cases of quadgroup functions? I've only seen one video mentioning them (\"Discovering advances in Metal for A15 Bionic\") where they're used to reduce the number of texture reads per thread. Are there any other use \"common\" use cases?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It can be used for any workload where you want to spread orthogonal work across a group; for instance, you can have each thread in a quad cull a part of a light list, then use quadgroup functions to peek at each others' lists and sum lights.

elements.text: It can be used for any workload where you want to spread orthogonal work across a group; for instance, you can have each thread in a quad cull a part of a light list, then use quadgroup functions to peek at each others' lists and sum lights.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The gist of quadgroup and simdgroup functions are to perform data exchange in a more efficient manner. Traditionally, threadgroup barrier and threadgroup memory is required to perform data exchanges, but its a lot more heavier than finer granularity exchanges like quadgroup or simdgroup functions.

elements.text: The gist of quadgroup and simdgroup functions are to perform data exchange in a more efficient manner. Traditionally, threadgroup barrier and threadgroup memory is required to perform data exchanges, but its a lot more heavier than finer granularity exchanges like quadgroup or simdgroup functions.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: When would you decide to use a quadgroup over a simdgroup function?

elements.text: When would you decide to use a quadgroup over a simdgroup function?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: When all you need is to exchange among 4 threads in a row.

elements.text: When all you need is to exchange among 4 threads in a row.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The finer granularity you use, the more efficient it is.

elements.text: The finer granularity you use, the more efficient it is.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If you are in compute, I would probably always use simdgroup, just to get the best bang for your buck. I believe quadgroups are interesting for fragment workloads; I'm not sure what the availability and details are by heart. (rasterization, helper threads etc)

elements.text: If you are in compute, I would probably always use simdgroup, just to get the best bang for your buck. I believe quadgroups are interesting for fragment workloads; I'm not sure what the availability and details are by heart. (rasterization, helper threads etc)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Metal RT is intended for use in both pure ray traced renderers and hybrid renderers that ray trace from rasterized content. This year's features are applicable to both with a focus on improving performance with some quality of life and ease of use features too! We have a Q&A session on Friday if you‚Äôd like to ask additional questions following the release of the video. Some of our samples, such as <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/metal_sample_code_library/accelerating_ray_tracing_using_metal|Accelerating Ray Tracing Using Metal> and <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/metal_sample_code_library/control_the_ray_tracing_process_using_intersection_queries|Control the Ray Tracing Process Using Intersection Queries> do pure ray tracing, and <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/metal_sample_code_library/rendering_reflections_in_real_time_using_ray_tracing|Rendering reflections in real time using ray tracing> uses a more hybrid model.

elements.text: Metal RT is intended for use in both pure ray traced renderers and hybrid renderers that ray trace from rasterized content. nodes to get that boost in FPS. I need to keep the nodes around, though, because they‚Äôre actionable individually - updating positions, backing contents, that kinda thing. It seems like I‚Äôd be able to do the same thing with a mesh by dynamically updating the mesh itself for things like positioning, and then figuring out how to map texture coordinates to those dynamically. I was even looking at ‚ÄòtextureCoordinates‚Äô as a potential option, but that exists on
, and all of my nodes with the same glyph share a geometry, again to keep total counts down.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi <@U03JRPTDF6U>, sorry for the late reply, as we closed down the Q&A, but if you want to discuss this more, please drop by the Q&A on Friday, or sign up for a Developer Lab, which is a 1:1 in-depth chat with one of our developers!

Just to quickly reply to your question, I do agree that you probably want to do this manually to remove a lot of the overhead. I'm not sure how familiar you are with mesh representations, but you should probably be able to do this by effectively writing your own "flatten" function. Without knowing where most of the performance is lost, I would suggest reading the nodes data manually and then composing the vertices for the mesh yourself. This would require you to manually create vertex and index data for your mesh and then upload and bind these to your Mesh.

I would suggest putting your question up in the Labs and indicate this is a SceneKit question - I think those folks will be better equipped to point out the best path :)

messages.text:
Today we answered some of your questions about Metal, the team enjoyed getting to hear more from the developers and hope that you all explore everything that Metal 3 has to offer :exploding_head:. These features and tools will enable your application or game to load resources faster, compile shader binaries at build time, process complex geometry with mesh shaders, render high-resolution graphics in less time, train machine learning networks faster, and much more. On behalf of the Metal team, thank you for joining this watch party and celebrating WWDC with us :relaxed:! We enjoyed the questions you asked and look forward to seeing what amazing apps and games you all will make with Metal 3 :partying_face:.

Continue sharing your WWDC experience with us by joining in on the other Digital Lounges that are going to be hosted throughout the week :calendar:. If you‚Äôd like to connect with some of the Metal team members to ask questions we have Labs that are available for sign up as well :female-scientist: (<https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/labs/>). The team enjoyed the conversations and questions posted here today, a lab session would be a great way to continue that discussion with someone on the team. And, as always, the <https://developer.apple.com/forums/tags/metal|Metal forums> are a great way to ask questions if you need help or run into issues.

Coming up next in the Games and Graphics Digital Lounge schedule will be the Watch Party for ScreenCapture Kit. We hope to see you there :eyes:! Have a good one and thanks again for joining :grin:.

messages.text:
<@U03J9S1L38W> asked
> With MetalFX are there any concerns or issues when dealing with transparency/volumetrics when doing temporal upscaling?  Would it sometimes be better to use Spatial upscaling and MSAA in some cases with a lot of transparency?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"With MetalFX are there any concerns or issues when dealing with transparency\/volumetrics when doing temporal upscaling?  Would it sometimes be better to use Spatial upscaling and MSAA in some cases with a lot of transparency?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Temporal AA requires full motion and depth information to produce the best result. Transparent objects usually do not provide that, so TAA will have insufficient input data to process everything correctly. Similar logic applies to reflections.

elements.text: Temporal AA requires full motion and depth information to produce the best result. Transparent objects usually do not provide that, so TAA will have insufficient input data to process everything correctly. Similar logic applies to reflections.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The choice will depend on your particular setup of the rendering pipeline. You could apply temporal upscaling to lower resolution color buffer with opaque objects only and then render transparent objects and volumetrics on top (in output resolution).

elements.text: The choice will depend on your particular setup of the rendering pipeline. You could apply temporal upscaling to lower resolution color buffer with opaque objects only and then render transparent objects and volumetrics on top (in output resolution).

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That makes sense, thanks.  Would the upscalers also work for targets other than the final tone mapped image, ie an AO pass?

elements.text: That makes sense, thanks.  Would the upscalers also work for targets other than the final tone mapped image, ie an AO pass?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes, you can do that. Just allocate separate scaling effect instances for those.

elements.text: Yes, you can do that. Just allocate separate scaling effect instances for those.

messages.text:
Good morning, all! Welcome to Meet ScreenCaptureKit Watch Party!! We‚Äôre stoked to have you here with us today as we dive into one our newest APIs at Apple, ScreenCaptureKit. My name is Troy and I‚Äôm a Program Manager for the ScreenCaptureKit team. In this hour, we invite everyone to <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10156/|watch Meet ScreenCaptureKit> together, make comments in the threads, and stick around for a little Q&A at the end. Queue up the video and be prepared to hit play at 11:05am PDT (I‚Äôll send a message when we‚Äôre ready to start).

In the meantime, I‚Äôm thrilled to introduce you to the speaker, Ernest! The rest of the ScreenCaptureKit team is also here, ready to watch along with you and answer your questions!

There‚Äôs a lot of us in the channel today, so we‚Äôll do our best to keep things organized. As the video progresses, I‚Äôll be creating threads associated with the various sections of the talk, where everyone can chat and ask questions (no spoilers if you‚Äôre zipping ahead at 2x!). ;)

When the video finishes, we‚Äôll have some time left over for targeted Q&A (I‚Äôll have more on that when we get there). So for the next few minutes, grab your popcorn, get comfy, and get ready to hit that play button soon!

messages.text:
<@U03JEEUJPMJ> asked
> Is system-level permission required even if an app only wants to capture /itself/ (i.e. only its own window(s)), and not anything external?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is system-level permission required even if an app only wants to capture \/itself\/ (i.e. only its own window(s)), and not anything external?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi Michael! Yes, system level permission (one time) is required for the initial time any applications wants to use ScreenCaptureKit. Even if the application is capturing itself, it'll need to get the SCShareableContent list in order to create a filter, which requires system level permission on the initial use.

elements.text: Hi Michael! Yes, system level permission (one time) is required for the initial time any applications wants to use ScreenCaptureKit. Even if the application is capturing itself, it'll need to get the SCShareableContent list in order to create a filter, which requires system level permission on the initial use.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Gotcha, gracias!

messages.text:
<@U03J2AD912N> asked
> Our video conferencing app offers screen sharing functionality, but we want the screen share video to exclude certain windows (e.g., A/V controls and floating participant videos). This is easily solvable with content filtering in ScreenCaptureKit, but what is the recommended way to get this behavior with older versions of macOS that do not support ScreenCaptureKit?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Our video conferencing app offers screen sharing functionality, but we want the screen share video to exclude certain windows (e.g., A\/V controls and floating participant videos). This is easily solvable with content filtering in ScreenCaptureKit, but what is the recommended way to get this behavior with older versions of macOS that do not support ScreenCaptureKit?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can use the screen capture portion of ScreenCaptureKit as of 12.3, and send it to other users using earlier versions of macOS. In order to get the maximum screen capture performance with ScreenCaptureKit, you'll need 12.3 or later. To achieve similar behavior in previous versions of macOS, you can use the `CGWindow` API to capture video, but not audio.

elements.text: You can use the screen capture portion of ScreenCaptureKit as of 12.3, and send it to other users using earlier versions of macOS. In order to get the maximum screen capture performance with ScreenCaptureKit, you'll need 12.3 or later. To achieve similar behavior in previous versions of macOS, you can use the
API to capture video, but not audio.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Specifically, CGWindowListCreate() and CGWindowListCreateImage(). They‚Äôre *much* slower than the other APIs, but available back to earlier MacOS versions.

elements.text: slower than the other APIs, but available back to earlier MacOS versions.

messages.text:
<@U03HVD5Q8DC> asked
> If you want to display the interactions with menu at the top of macOS, does that constrain you to just capturing a display (vs. application or window) in order to show that?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"If you want to display the interactions with menu at the top of macOS, does that constrain you to just capturing a display (vs. application or window) in order to show that?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can use `init(display:including:exceptingWindows:)`, but this will capture the surface the size of the desktop. The app will be positioned as it is in the desktop, and the menu bar will be at the top of the capture.

elements.text: , but this will capture the surface the size of the desktop. The app will be positioned as it is in the desktop, and the menu bar will be at the top of the capture.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Ah, brilliant! Thank you!

<@U03JEEUJPMJ> asked
> I make media /playback/ systems, but haven't really yet played with /producing/ media‚Äì could you give me an idea of what the next steps would be (in terms of macOS frameworks/API usage), to go from ScreenCaptureKit's sample buffers, to, say, a 'playback-ready' H264/HEVC+AAC HLS output?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I make media \/playback\/ systems, but haven't really yet played with \/producing\/ media\u2013 could you give me an idea of what the next steps would be (in terms of macOS frameworks\/API usage), to go from ScreenCaptureKit's sample buffers, to, say, a 'playback-ready' H264\/HEVC+AAC HLS output?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi Michael!

ScreenCaptureKit gives samples back as CMSampleBuffers. So if you wanted to make it playback ready, I would suggest you use AVAssetWriter to create a movie. This should allow you create a movie with the output you wish

elements.text:
Hi Michael!

ScreenCaptureKit gives samples back as CMSampleBuffers. So if you wanted to make it playback ready, I would suggest you use AVAssetWriter to create a movie. This should allow you create a movie with the output you wish

slackdump_thread_replies.text: For HLS, you're going to use VideoToolBox to fragmented mp4 files that you can then upload to the server and update your HLS playlist

elements.text: For HLS, you're going to use VideoToolBox to fragmented mp4 files that you can then upload to the server and update your HLS playlist

slackdump_thread_replies.text: And if you need a CBR-based stream, Ventura added hardware-encoding-based H.264 and HEVC CBR support, so you can offload the work from the CPU.

elements.text: And if you need a CBR-based stream, Ventura added hardware-encoding-based H.264 and HEVC CBR support, so you can offload the work from the CPU.

messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"One thing that wasn't totally clear to me from the videos: Obviously, audio-capture is per-application, since audio is not associated with a window. If I exclude only *some* windows of an application from capture, does that mean I don't get any audio?"}]}

messages.text:
:relaxed: Welcome to *Meet the Presenter: Boost your performance with MetalFX Upscaling*. We‚Äôre extremely enthusiastic to have you with us today. I‚Äôm Henry, an Engineering Project Manager in Graphics Software and the host for this Digital Lounge. We‚Äôll start the watch party followed by Q & A after the video completes. In this hour, for a great experience, we ask for you to start watching the video <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10103|Boost performance with MetalFX Upscaling> at *1:05 pm PDT*.

In the meantime, we‚Äôre excited to introduce you to the presenter and speaker, Kelvin, a GPU Software Engineer :clap:. In addition, we‚Äôre joined here by many engineers that worked on Metal, ready to answer your questions! There are a lot of us here, so we will do our best to keep things organized.

As the video progresses, we‚Äôll create threads :thread: associated with each section of the talk, where everyone can chat and react. After the video finishes playing, please stick around! We will open a slack workflow so you can submit your questions to our awesome Metal team.

In this talk, we‚Äôll introduce you to MetalFX, a new API that provides platform-optimized graphics effects for Metal applications. With MetalFX Upscaling, your application can now render frames at a lower resolution, reducing rendering time without compromising rendering quality :exploding_head:. So, make sure you have your popcorn :popcorn: ready and feel free to drop a reaction or join in on the conversation when you see something that interests :raised_hands: you!

.

In the meantime, we‚Äôre excited to introduce you to the presenter and speaker, Kelvin, a GPU Software Engineer

. In addition, we‚Äôre joined here by many engineers that worked on Metal, ready to answer your questions! There are a lot of us here, so we will do our best to keep things organized.

As the video progresses, we‚Äôll create threads

associated with each section of the talk, where everyone can chat and react. After the video finishes playing, please stick around! We will open a slack workflow so you can submit your questions to our awesome Metal team.

In this talk, we‚Äôll introduce you to MetalFX, a new API that provides platform-optimized graphics effects for Metal applications. With MetalFX Upscaling, your application can now render frames at a lower resolution, reducing rendering time without compromising rendering quality
. So, make sure you have your popcorn
ready and feel free to drop a reaction or join in on the conversation when you see something that interests

<@U03K19A2324> asked
> Why use a constant jitter offset for a set of pixels instead of a random one that would probably make the result more smoother?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Why use a constant jitter offset for a set of pixels instead of a random one that would probably make the result more smoother?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Using a fixed set of low-discrepancy jitter offsets ensures that the space of potential jitters is covered relatively evenly for any given window in time.

messages.text:
<@U03K19A2324> asked
> Wonderful presentation @Kevin! Thank you very much! The technology works beautifully with slow moving scenes. Could you comment on the impact of using temporal information on quick moving scenes or quick changing content? Should there be some adaptive setting with respect to the amount of previous pixels used based on the richness/rate of change of the scene's content?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Wonderful presentation @Kevin! Thank you very much! The technology works beautifully with slow moving scenes. Could you comment on the impact of using temporal information on quick moving scenes or quick changing content? Should there be some adaptive setting with respect to the amount of previous pixels used based on the richness\/rate of change of the scene's content?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks. If the scene is truly moving super quick, where there's very little temporal information that can be reused, the result will simply not be as high resolution and anti-aliased. We do expect this to work as well as the amount of information that's present and for things to be more refined as motion slows.

elements.text: Thanks. If the scene is truly moving super quick, where there's very little temporal information that can be reused, the result will simply not be as high resolution and anti-aliased. We do expect this to work as well as the amount of information that's present and for things to be more refined as motion slows.

elements.text: We cannot comment on particular implementation details of MetalFX framework.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you <@U03H3GQDUP9> for your answer. :slightly_smiling_face: I wouldn't say using ML for upscaling is an implementation detail, but rather a radically different approach to classical upscaling methods. Of course, it has its own implementation details, should one opts to actually build it (that naturally can't be shared). However, my question was about the approach itself and wether it is under consideration (and, of course, not any specifics on its implementation).

elements.text: I wouldn't say using ML for upscaling is an implementation detail, but rather a radically different approach to classical upscaling methods. <@U03HY66772A> asked
> What is the best way to render biplanar EDR cvpixelbuffer from avfoundation in Metal? Is better to convert pixelbuffer into mtltexture via compute, or sample from 2 mtltextures created from each plane?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the best way to render biplanar EDR cvpixelbuffer from avfoundation in Metal? Is better to convert pixelbuffer into mtltexture via compute, or sample from 2 mtltextures created from each plane?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
To render EDR CVPixelBuffer contents using Metal you‚Äôd need following:
‚Ä¢ Setup CAMetalLayer to accept EDR values using `CAMetalLayer.wantsExtendedDynamicRangeContent` property set to `YES`
‚Ä¢ Create MTLTexture instances that shares corresponding IOSurface from CVPixelBuffer
‚Ä¢ Use them for rendering

Yes, please do!

Regarding the display shape, look into safe area insets: <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appkit/nsscreen/3882821-safeareainsets|https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appkit/nsscreen/3882821-safeareainsets>

I just confirmed with the responsible engineering team that as long as nothing else is drawing atop your full screen NSWindow, you will be on the fastest-performance drawing path through the compositor.

messages.text:
<@U03J21F2PQS> asked
> Hello everybody! Is there any sample or instructions how to make offscreen render using Metal? For example: I have a scene and I want to save it as png file. How can I do it? Can I control resolution of saved file?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hello everybody! Is there any sample or instructions how to make offscreen render using Metal? For example: I have a scene and I want to save it as png file. How can I do it? Can I control resolution of saved file?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
To offscreen render a scene and save it as a PNG file, you may first render the scene into a MTLTexture with the desired resolution. The texture will need to be a <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/mtltextureusage/1515701-rendertarget
|render target>.

Then there are a few different ways to get a CGImage from the MTLTexture: A quick way will be to <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/coreimage/ciimage/1437890-init
|initialize a CIImage> with the MTLTexture and then <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/coreimage/cicontext/1437784-createcgimage
|use a CIContext to create the CGImage>, which you can use to write to disk.

elements.text: To offscreen render a scene and save it as a PNG file, you may first render the scene into a MTLTexture with the desired resolution. The texture will need to be a

.

Then there are a few different ways to get a CGImage from the MTLTexture: A quick way will be to
use a CIContext to create the CGImage
, which you can use to write to disk.

messages.text:
Today we learned about MetalFX Upscaling, which allows you to render high-resolution graphics in less time! On behalf of the Metal team, thank you for joining this watch party and celebrating WWDC with us :relaxed:! We enjoyed the questions you asked and look forward to seeing what amazing apps and games you all will make with MetalFX Upscaling :partying_face:.
Continue sharing your WWDC experience with us by joining the other Digital Lounges hosted throughout the week :calendar:. If you‚Äôd like to connect with some of the Metal team members to ask questions we have Labs that are available for sign up as well :female-scientist:. And, as always, the Metal forums are a great way to ask questions if you need help or run into issues.
Coming up next in the Games and Graphics Digital Lounge schedule will be the Next Level ScreenCaptureKit Watch Party at 3-4 pm PDT and our casual Icebreaker at 5-6 pm PDT. We hope to see you there :eyes:! Have a good one and thanks again for joining :grin:.

messages.text:
Good afternoon, all! Ready to take a deep dive on Apple‚Äôs new content streaming API, ScreenCaptureKit? Join us as we dive into the amazing flexibility that ScreenCaptureKit offers with content filtering, frame contorl and metadata, and audio! It‚Äôs the Meet the Presenter: <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10155/|Take Screen Capture Kit to the Next Level>!!

We‚Äôre stoked to have you here with us today as we dive deeper into one our newest APIs at Apple. My name is Troy and I‚Äôm a Program Manager for the ScreenCaptureKit team. In this hour, we invite everyone to watch Take ScreenCaptureKit to the Next Level video together, make comments in the threads, and stick around for a little Q&A at the end. Queue up the video and be prepared to hit play at 3:05pm PDT (I‚Äôll send a message when we‚Äôre ready to start).

In the meantime, I‚Äôm thrilled to introduce you to the speakers, Meng and Drew! The rest of the ScreenCaptureKit team is also here, ready to watch along with you and answer your questions!

There‚Äôs a lot of us here, so we‚Äôll do our best to keep things organized. As the video progresses, I‚Äôll be creating threads associated with each section of the talk, where everyone can chat and ask questions (no spoilers if you‚Äôre zipping ahead at 2x!). ;)

When the video finishes, we‚Äôll have some time left over for targeted Q&A (I‚Äôll have more on that when we get there). So for the next few minutes, slick your hair and grab your buckle shoes, and get ready to hit that play button soon!

messages.text:
<@U03JZ218ZUY> asked
> I'm sorry, I wasn't able to watch the video, so just wanted to confirm: with ScreenCaptureKit we're able to capture the mixed system sound, or filter in or out the applications that we want or don't want to include, right? For example capture sounds from my own application + Zoom call already mixed for us, basically replacing things like Blackhole + Multi-Output/Device etc?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I'm sorry, I wasn't able to watch the video, so just wanted to confirm: with ScreenCaptureKit we're able to capture the mixed system sound, or filter in or out the applications that we want or don't want to include, right? For example capture sounds from my own application + Zoom call already mixed for us, basically replacing things like Blackhole + Multi-Output\/Device etc?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes, absolutely! In this case, you might want to use `init(display:excludingApplications:exceptingWindows:)`, where you can capture all audio, excluding the applications that you don't want in the audio.

elements.text: Yes, absolutely! In this case, you might want to use
, where you can capture all audio, excluding the applications that you don't want in the audio.

messages.text: Hey everyone! Thanks much for joining us in our games and graphics icebreaker event! We‚Äôve got a number of engineers from various GPU Software and Game technology teams from Apple here. We‚Äôre eager to get to know our developers better and just have a little fun interacting with you all.

elements.text: Hey everyone! Thanks much for joining us in our games and graphics icebreaker event! We‚Äôve got a number of engineers from various GPU Software and Game technology teams from Apple here. We‚Äôre eager to get to know our developers better and just have a little fun interacting with you all.

messages.text: I‚Äôm personally really looking forward to this after several busy weeks of prepping for WWDC22 and the announcement of Metal 3.

elements.text: I‚Äôm personally really looking forward to this after several busy weeks of prepping for WWDC22 and the announcement of Metal 3.

I remember shipping a Water consumption app probably around 2014, and upon launch it had this animation where the icon expanding to reveal the UI behind it (similar to how Twitter does today where the bird grows larger (very quickly) and reveals the Twitter UI). :smile:

I wrote some intermediate shading language spec for a GPU company I used to work for when I was a junior engineer and didn't know what I was doing.   Then 15 years later, Apple was working with that same company, and I saw  my name was still on that damn spec.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03HJ41GWAX>: Okay, since you asked for it: Using statistics to cull objects for a shadow map pass, i.e. outliers in terms of AABB size won't be drawn at all. Meant to counter the ideas of content creators like: floor plane of practically infinite size is a good thing (which quickly destroys shadow map precision). It shipped and worked surprisingly well.

Proudest moment: my first time walking into a music video bar, which has screens covering every wall, and seeing the (music video + overlaid animated customer tweets + animated venue logo) output of my app displaying on every one of the screens, and hearing the (music) output of my app blasting through the speakers. :raised_hands::skin-tone-3:

Most ashamed of: a pretty bad bug meant that audio would, at random, glitch out (like a CD skipping) to silence after a few seconds‚Äî until I could get to the bottom of it, I made available a web page, with a single giant button, which let venue staff remotely-relaunch the macOS app from their phones :eyes:

messages.text: Any game algorithm, graphics technique you‚Äôre excited about?  Think any of these are going to "revolutionize" gaming?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Temporal upscalers enhanced with AI techniques. Allows to keep compute needs down while retaining a high level of fidelity. And hardware ray-tracing, although we aren't at the point where it's possible to ship a fully path-traced game for general use yet.

elements.text: Temporal upscalers enhanced with AI techniques. Allows to keep compute needs down while retaining a high level of fidelity. And hardware ray-tracing, although we aren't at the point where it's possible to ship a fully path-traced game for general use yet.

messages.text:
<@U03JF5PC27R> asked
> what is the fastest way to get something on screen with Metal? is there way to draw directly to screen instead of metal layer contents and then wait for frame composing?
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"what is the fastest way to get something on screen with Metal? is there way to draw directly to screen instead of metal layer contents and then wait for frame composing?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The fastest way to get your drawing on-screen is to create a full-screen CAMetalLayer. You can also optionally set `displaySyncEnabled` to false on your layer to render faster than the display‚Äôs refresh rate at the cost of potential artifacts.

elements.text: The fastest way to get your drawing on-screen is to create a full-screen CAMetalLayer. You can also optionally set
to false on your layer to render faster than the display‚Äôs refresh rate at the cost of potential artifacts.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Be sure to take advantage of a ProMotion display if the user has it, too! You can set a minimum and maximum CADisplayLink callback rate using a CAFrameRateRange, for instance.

elements.text: Be sure to take advantage of a ProMotion display if the user has it, too! You can set a minimum and maximum CADisplayLink callback rate using a CAFrameRateRange, for instance.

messages.text:
<@U03JWBY2PH8> asked
> Might anyone be able to speak to whether it makes sense to combine indirect command buffers (<https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/indirect_command_encoding/encoding_indirect_command_buffers_on_the_gpu?language=objc|https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/indirect_command_encoding/encoding_indirect_command_buffers_on_the_gpu?language=objc> ) with bindless rendering *and* dynamic data? Specifically, I am trying to avoid a lot of draw calls. With the SOC architecture, it seems passing data is not really expensive, so I figure per-frame I could just specify some parameters and generate draw calls on the GPU, as in the example.
> 
> -broad question, I realize, but I'd appreciate some thoughts on how to reduce draw calls for rapidly-updated and/or deleted vertex data.
> 
> I also checked mesh shaders, but I think those are overkill for my use case.
messages.username: Graphics and Games - Ask a Question

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi Karl! Metal 3 adds support for starting raytracing work from ICBs. ICBs give you more flexibility at rendering time, but this flexibility does come with a cost that will vary according to your specific use case. For example ICBs will give you the edge when you are CPU-bound. As with all things related to performance, we recommend you profile your game (or app) :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hi Karl! Metal 3 adds support for starting raytracing work from ICBs. ICBs give you more flexibility at rendering time, but this flexibility does come with a cost that will vary according to your specific use case. For example ICBs will give you the edge when you are CPU-bound. As with all things related to performance, we recommend you profile your game (or app)

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi! Thanks for the reply, and I agree I should always profile. To clarify, I‚Äôm not doing raytracing, so perhaps this is pre-optimization, but while WWDC is happening, I thought I‚Äôd ask a follow-up question:

Since you mention ICB-use cost, what would you say the common tradeoffs are with ICBs?
Also, do you imagine them working well with bindless rendering?
For example, let‚Äôs many textures and my entire scene in a buffer within an argument buffer.
Would it then make sense to use an ICB to issue draw calls on the scene stored that way?

However, I suspect that ICBs and bindless are orthogonal.

Thanks again for your time!

elements.text:
Hi! Thanks for the reply, and I agree I should always profile. To clarify, I‚Äôm not doing raytracing, so perhaps this is pre-optimization, but while WWDC is happening, I thought I‚Äôd ask a follow-up question:

Since you mention ICB-use cost, what would you say the common tradeoffs are with ICBs?
Also, do you imagine them working well with bindless rendering?
For example, let‚Äôs many textures and my entire scene in a buffer within an argument buffer.
Would it then make sense to use an ICB to issue draw calls on the scene stored that way?

However, I suspect that ICBs and bindless are orthogonal.

Thanks again for your time!

messages.text:
Hello there ~ Welcome to Meet the Presenter - *<https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10064/|Reach new players with Game Center dashboard>* watch party :partying_face:! My name is Joshua from the Game Center team, I‚Äôll be your guide through this digital lounge. I‚Äôm excited to introduce you to our speaker Knott. As an engineer on the Game Center team Knott is excited to share with you whats coming to Game Center.

We invite everyone to watch the *<https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10064/|Reach new players with Game Center dashboard>* together at 11:05 PDT. We‚Äôre joined here by almost the entire Game Center team, ready to answer your questions!! There‚Äôs a lot of us here, so we‚Äôre going to do our best to keep things organized.

As we watch the video together I‚Äôll be creating threads (:thread:) for each section of the presentation please feel free to chat and react with the Game Center team.

Queue up that video and get ready to hit play at *11:05 PDT.*
Video Link: *<https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10064/>*

After the video we‚Äôll have some time for an additional targeted Q&A. We‚Äôll enable a Slack workflow that allows you to submit any questions you have, we‚Äôll do our best to answer as many as we can. (To ask a question, Click the Plus button (:heavy_plus_sign:) in the lower left of the chat then find the ‚ÄúAsk a Question‚Äù :zap:.)
